keyDevelopments: New administration's first six months established policy direction across all domains
Initial executive orders on immigration, trade, and regulatory reform set the tone
DOJ leadership transition completed with new priorities announced; 17 inspectors general fired in January

changes.summary: Escalation of executive actions and early institutional friction
keyDevelopments: Courts ruled mass IG firings unlawful but declined reinstatement, establishing pattern of unenforceable rulings
Liberation Day tariffs imposed 10% baseline on all imports with higher rates for China; trade war escalation began
CIA offered buyouts to entire workforce; intelligence community independence concerns emerged

categoryChanges.rationale: CIA workforce buyout offer and early signs of intelligence politicization; DNI began reassigning analysts producing inconvenient assessments
Liberation Day tariffs announced; 10% baseline on all imports with country-specific rates up to 49% for China
Firing of 17 inspectors general in single action; courts ruled action unlawful but declined to order reinstatement; DOGE gained access to sensitive federal payment and personnel systems

changes.summary: Intelligence community concerns emerge; regulatory shifts accelerate
keyDevelopments: Sen. Warner's floor speech warning of systematic undermining of intelligence community independence
Schedule F executive order reinstated, reclassifying career civil service positions as at-will
Voting restrictions advanced in multiple states ahead of 2026 midterms

categoryChanges.rationale: Multiple states advanced proof-of-citizenship requirements; DOJ began requesting voter registration files from states
DOJ restructuring under AG Bondi accelerated; career ethics officials purged; politically-motivated case decisions increased
January 6 pardons for ~1,500 defendants including seditious conspiracy convictions generated significant public division

changes.summary: Election administration concerns intensify; broad-based risk escalation
keyDevelopments: 16 states enacted 29 new restrictive voting laws, with 28 taking effect before 2026 midterms
University funding threats escalated with Harvard grant terminations totaling $2.2B
DOGE-led contract terminations exceeded 6,000; government shutdown briefly halted operations

categoryChanges.rationale: Wave of state voting restrictions took effect; seven states passed stricter voter ID laws requiring birth certificates or passports
DNI budget cuts of $700M+ to intelligence offices; intelligence resources increasingly diverted to domestic priorities
Government operating under continuing resolutions; DOGE workforce reductions beginning to impact agency capacity
FCC opened investigations into ABC, NBC, CBS over election coverage; Paramount settled with Trump under merger pressure

changes.summary: Judicial conflicts escalate across multiple fronts; broadest monthly increase
keyDevelopments: Deputy AG declared administration 'at war' with federal judiciary at Federalist Society conference
100+ DOJ prosecutors resigned citing political interference; threats against judges tripled
Trade tariffs on China reached 145%; retaliatory tariffs at 125%; trade deficit widened $175B

categoryChanges.rationale: NYC Bar Association condemned DOJ 'war on judiciary' remarks; mass prosecutor resignations over politically-motivated case decisions
US-China retaliatory spiral reached 145%/125% tariff levels; Court of International Trade ruled tariffs exceeded presidential authority
Threats against federal judges tripled; pardoned January 6 defendants called for retribution against prosecutors and police
Executive order count exceeded 200; AI EO reversed Biden-era safeguards; contradictory guidance created compliance chaos
DOGE-led contract consolidation exceeded 6,000 terminations; White House ballroom donors with $279B in contracts identified
Seven universities rejected 'Compact for Academic Excellence'; Cornell and Northwestern face $1B+ funding pauses

changes.summary: Federal Reserve independence threatened; year-end institutional strain
keyDevelopments: Unprecedented attempt to fire Fed Governor Lisa Cook; DOJ probe of Federal Reserve announced
Intelligence Authorization Act included politicization safeguards, reflecting bipartisan concern
Administration appointed Stephen Miran to Fed board while retaining admin position; sole dissent on rates

categoryChanges.rationale: Administration pattern of delayed compliance with court orders crystallized across immigration, environmental, and civil rights cases
DNI fired National Intelligence Council officials over Venezuela assessment; intelligence resources diverted to Greenland proposal
Unprecedented attempt to remove Fed governor; DOJ investigation of Fed signaled direct executive branch interference with monetary policy

changes.summary: One-year mark shows sustained institutional pressure across all domains
keyDevelopments: Overall risk elevated to High (7.3) from Elevated baseline
All 10 categories show 'increasing' trend direction
Rule of Law domain highest at 8.0 average; 235 executive orders signed in first year

categoryChanges.rationale: Cumulative effect of 108 restrictive laws since 2020; 28 new restrictions taking effect before 2026 midterms; Trump called for 'nationalizing' voting
Schedule F implementation affecting 50,000 federal employees; replacement IGs confirmed from former Trump administration staff; CIGIE defunded

changes.summary: Minnesota crisis, Supreme Court injunction ruling, and government shutdown drive largest monthly increase
keyDevelopments: Two U.S. citizens fatally shot by ICE/CBP agents in Minneapolis; nationwide protests and Minnesota general strike followed
Supreme Court 6-3 ruling eliminated nationwide injunctions, gutting primary judicial check on executive overreach
Four-day partial government shutdown (Jan 30–Feb 3); DHS funded only through Feb 13 amid ICE enforcement dispute

categoryChanges.rationale: SCOTUS eliminated nationwide injunctions 6-3; court granted 66 emergency stays for administration; Congress moved to impeach judges; ICE violated 96+ court orders in Minnesota
SCOTUS injunction ruling dramatically reduces ability to challenge regulatory overreach in court; 235 EOs now signed; Schedule F final rule imminent
Four-day government shutdown; DHS funded only 2 weeks; DOGE claimed $215B in savings but independent analyses estimate net cost of $21.7B–$135B; 300K+ federal workers departed
FCC opened NPR/PBS inquiry linked to defunding effort; US dropped to 55th in press freedom (lowest ever); journalists arrested at Minnesota protests
Two U.S. citizens killed by federal immigration agents; Minnesota general strike Jan 23; nationwide 'no work, no school' protests Jan 30; DOJ investigating governor while arresting church protesters
300K+ federal employees departed (212K+ forced out); replacement IGs are former Trump officials; CIGIE defunded; SCOTUS gutted nationwide injunctions; IG offices lost 20-30% staff
